MC Vital Statistics 1960-1972
 
1960
Martha R. Gatten
Source:  The Monroe County Beacon, Woodsfield, Ohio, dated, May 23, 1960
Martha R. Gatten, daughter of Obadiah and Sarah Sparks Nalley, was born in Wayne Township, Monroe County, Ohio, on March 19, 1884, and departed this life on March 30, 1960, being at the time of her death, 76 years and eleven days of age.
She was united in marriage with John Gatten on August 5, 1905. She was a devoted wife, a loving mother, and a good neighbor.
She was a member of The Richfork Church of Christ.
Surviving are her husband and five children, Floyd Gatten, of Woodsfield, Route 2; Mrs. Flavil Bates, of Woodsfield, Route 3; Mrs. Evalee Harold and Mrs. Winona Abricht, of Marietta, Ohio, and Mrs. Irene Stultz, of Ashland, Ohio.  Also, surviving are fourteen grandchildren; seven great grandchildren; one brother, George Nalley, of Creston, Ohio, and two sisters, Mrs. Nora Fisher, of Akron, Ohio, and Mrs. Laura Smith, of Oregon. Besides these, she leaves other relatives and many friends.
One son, John Junior, two grandsons, and one great-granddaughter, preceded her in death.
 
       "You bade none the last farewell,
          You said good-bye to none;
         The heavenly gates opened
        And a lovely voice said "Come."
 
         Honest and faithful in her ways,
        Devoted and true to the end of her days;
        A loving wife and mother so kind,
         What a beautiful memory she left behind."
 
       Funeral services were conducted by Minister J. V. A.  Traylor at The Bauer and Turner Funeral Chapel on Saturday afternoon, April 2nd, at two o'clock. Burial was made in Oaklawn Cemetery, Woodsfield, Ohio.
 
1960
       Gerald Aldine Highman
(Published in The Monroe County Beacon, Thursday, June 2, 1960
   "Since life, at best, is uncertain and death is sure, the imperative question is not 'how life shall be lived,' but how one chooses to die"
    Gerald Aldine Highman was born May 6,1905, in Monroe County, Ohio, the son of the late Charles F. and Pearl Nalley Highman. He departed this life Mar.15,1960 at his home on Lewisville,Oh., Rt.2, being at the time of his death 54 years,ten months and ten days of age.
   In addition to his parents, he was preceded in death by one brother, Leland D. Highman, a casualty of World War II.
   Survivors include his wife, Thelma Heskett Highman, three children; Harold, of Woodsfield; Merril Highman of Columbus; and Virginia Cecil, of Lewisville, Rt.2 and five grandchildren. Two brothers, Glen Highman,of Woodsfield, and Edsel Highman of Graysville, Route; and three sisters ,Waneta Dalrymple, of Dayton; Audrey Gatten and Mabel Hines, both of Lewisville, Route,  also survive; as well as a host of nephews and nieces.
   At an early age the deceased became a member of The Methodist Church. Reared in southeastern Ohio, he was associated in his youth with the W.E. Lamneck Company of Columbus and Middletown,Oh. In middle-age he returned to the Lewisville community to engage in agricultural and business pursuits. He endeared himself not only to his family but to his many friends,who knew him by his consistant loyalty and constant good humor.
   Funeral services were held in The Bauer and Turner Funeral Chapel on Sat. p.m. at two o'clock, with Rev. John Grimes, of The Free Methodist Church, officiating. Interment was in Oaklawn Cemetery. 
 
1960XXXXXX
MARRIAGE
Mr. Robert Eugene Morris
and Miss Dorothy Lee Hoff
Source: The Monroe County Beacon
Woodsfield, Ohio, Monday, June 20, 1960
 
Miss Dorothy Lee Hoff became the bride of Robert Eugene Morris in a ceremony performed Saturday evening, April twenty-third, 1960 at St. Peters United Church of Christ (Evangelical and Reformed), Lewisville, Ohio.
The bride is the youngest daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ernest Hoff, of Lewisville, Route 2. The groom is the oldest son of Mr. and Mrs. Ermie Morris, of Woodsfield, Route 3.
The Reverend George W. Varns officiated at the double ring ceremony and sang the Lords Prayer at the close of the ceremony. Mrs. Amos DeWitt presented a one-half hour of nuptial music.
Given in marriage by her father, the bride chose a floor-length gown of acetate-nylon lace over acetate taffeta.
Miss Sara Rose Morris, sister of the groom, was her only attendant.
Richard Weber, cousin of the bride, served as best man. Ushers were Byron Morris, brother of the groom, and Robert Weber, cousin of the bride. The candles were lighted by Donald Weber, cousin of the bride.
Immediately following the ceremony, a reception for over two hundred guests was held at Fellowship Hall, near Lewisville. Assisting at the reception were Miss Charlotte Mobley, Miss Alice Reich, Miss Betty Lou Morris, Mrs. Willard Weber, Mrs. Francis Heft and Miss Ruth Hinderlong. Miss Betty Lou Morris, sister of the groom, presided over the guest book.
Mr. and Mrs. Morris are graduates of Lewisville High School, class of 1957. Mrs. Morris is employed with the Campus Shirt Company at Barnesville, Ohio. Mr. Morris is employed by Robert Butlers Trucking, of Barnesville. The couple is residing in their newly purchased home at 325 Hunts Avenue, Barnesville.
 
 

DEATH

1960X

Lewis P. Christman

Source: Monroe Co. Beacon

 

Lewis P. Christman, age 91, born January 23, 1869, near Lewisville, passed away Wednesday morning, February 3 at the home of his son Roy, in Woodsfield after an extended illness.

He had resided at the home of his sister, Mrs. Anna Weber at Lewisville for the past several years.

His wife, Ida Paulus Christman, preceded him in death on January 26, 1944.

Surviving are one daughter, Mrs. Freda Hamilton, of Short Creek, W. Va.; five sons, Dr. Nova Christman, Roy Christman, Walter Chirstman and Clayton Christman, all of Woodsfield and John Christman, of Akron; eighteen grandchildren; five sisters, Miss Louisa Christman, Miss Tillie Christman, Mrs. Anna Weber and Mrs. Lewis Heft, all of Lewisville, and Mrs. Mary Ackerman of Woodsfield, and one brother, George II Christman, of Woodsfield.

Friends are being received at the Bauer-Turner Funeral Home where services will be held Friday afternoon at 2:00 o'clock. Burial will be in Oaklawn Cemetery.

October 27, 1960XXXXX

DEATH

Henri C. Ackerman

Source: Monroe County Beacon

 

Henri C. Ackerman, 91, of Somerton died Monday morning, October 17, 1960. At 10:15 o'clock, at the home of his daughter, Mrs. Clem Froechlich, on Barnesville, Route 1.

He was born November 27, 1868 in Benwood, W. Va., a son of Herman and Mary Niesz Ackerman, and had resided there for some time. He was a member of the Methodist Church.

Surviving are three sons, Sam Ackerman of Malaga; George Ackerman and Clarence Ackerman of Somerton; four daughters, Mrs. Alfreda Froehlich, Mrs. Mary Fisher and Mrs. Trella Froehlich, all of Barnesville Route and Mrs. Stella Nepture, of Kansas City, Kansas; two sisters, Mrs. Clara Christman, of Calais and Mrs. Tillie Sebach, of Alliance, Ohio. One son, Roy is deceased. His wife Louise died in 1919.

Funeral services were held Wednesday afternoon at two o'clock in the Methodist Church at Somerton with the Rev. William Irvin officiating. Interment was in the Somerton Cemetery.

 

 
1960XXXXX
PAUL F. ARMBRUSTER
[Source: Wheeling News Register, Thursday, November 10, 1960]
ARMBRUSTER, Paul F., 55, a resident of Temperanceville, near Barnesville, was found dead Wednesday morning. He was born at Temperanceville on September 3, 1905, a son of George and Alice Armbruster. A veteran of World War II, he had been employed at Mansfield, Ohio, for several years. Surviving are one brother, George, Akron, and two sisters, Mrs. Norbert Flutterer and Mrs. Vinton J. Gehradt, both of Columbus. The body has been removed to the Campbell Funeral Home, Barnesville. Funeral services will not be held, but interment will be in Beaver Cemetery, near Calais.

December 20, 1960X

DEATH

Benjamin F. Palzgraf

Source: Monroe County Beacon

 

Word has been received here of the death of Benjamin F. Palzgraf, a native of Woodsfield, who died on Friday November 25, 1960, at the Weld County Hospital in Colorado.

Mr. Palzgraf, a well-known farmer who lived near Farmers Spur northwest of Greeley, Colorado, was born December 18, 1880, in Woodsfield. He was graduated from the University of Colorado Law school in 1908.

He married Gladys Decker, July 8, 1908 in Greeley.

Mr. Palzgraf was a member of the First Methodist Church, Greeley Lodge No. 489 BPOE, and several farm organizations.

He is survived by his wife; three sons and two daughter, Lt. Col. B. A. Palzgraf, of Los Angeles, California; John M. Palzgraf, of Aurora; Lt. Col. B. G. Falzgraf, of Redlands, California; Mrs. Lee Kerns, of Kansas City, Missouri, and Mrs. Conrad Kunze, of LaMesa, California; one brother and three sisters, Sam Pfalzgraf of Cameron, Ohio; Mrs. Barbara Walton, of Mingo Junction, Ohio; Mrs. Louise Metzgar, of Pittsburgh, Pa., and Mrs. Mary Pfalzgarf, of Boulder, Colorado. Also surviving are eleven grandchildren.

Funeral services were held Tuesday afternoon at two o'clock in the Adamson Memorial Chapel. Interment was in Linn Grove.

1961X
DEATHXXXXX
Name: Mrs. Eva Elizabeth Betts,nee Rubel
Source: The Monroe County Beacon
Issue: Woodsfield, Ohio, January 1961
Collection of Mary Eva Betts Christman
Mrs. Eva Elizabeth Betts, 94, died at 4:30 p.m. on Thursday, January 5, 1961, in the home of her daughter, Mrs. L. O. Graham, 56 Roberts Drive, Shelby, Ohio. Mrs. Betts was a former resident of the community and leaves a number of relatives near Tiro.
Mrs. Betts had been in failing health for the past two years and seriously ill for several weeks. She enjoyed a long and active life, spending her time in recent years with her children.
The deceased was born in Seneca Township, Monroe County, Ohio, on April 2, 1866 to Jacob and Barbara Pfalzgraf Rubel. She was married to John A. Taylor, September 11, 1884. He died march 17, 1901. To this union seven children were born: Mrs. Barbara Kurzen, of Akron, Ohio; J. Albert Taylor, of Bucyrus, Ohio; George A. Taylor, of Akron; Clarence O. Taylor, of Mt. Gilead, and Rose Marie Loomis, of LaMesa, California. Two children, Mrs. Mary Louise Gardner, of Akron, and John A. Taylor, of Bucyrus, preceded her in death.
On July 11, 1903 the deceased was united in marriage to Joseph H. Betts, who preceded her in death on May 23, 1952 while the couple was living in New Washington. Mr. and Mrs. Betts had four children: Theodore F. Betts, of Tiro, Route 1; Guy Betts, of Barberton, Ohio; Mrs. Sarah E. Graham and Lawrence A. Betts, both of Shelby, and formerly of near Tiro.
Mrs. Betts is survived by thirty-three grandchildren, sixty-three great grandchildren and one great-great granddaughter. Three grandchildren and two great grandchildren are deceased. Also surviving are two sisters, Mrs. Mary Goodhart, of Summerfield, and Mrs. Rosa Betts, of Lewisville. Three brothers, John, Lewis, and George Rubel, are deceased.
Mr. and Mrs. Betts and family moved to Crawford County. Ohio on December 10, 1924, setting in Liberty township near Bucyrus, Ohio. Mrs. Betts spent most of her life since then in Crawford County. She and Mr. Betts moved to the Cleland Farm, now the home of Mr. and Mrs. E. Shott, southwest of Tiro in March 1931. In 1949 they moved to New Washington and lived there until Mrs. Betts death in 1952.
Mrs. Betts was a member of the Tiro Evangelical United Brethren Church and the pastor, Reverend Joseph Phillips, conducted funeral services in the Church on Saturday at 1:30 p.m. He based his sermon on the theme of being willing to wait but ready to go. Reverend Joseph Graham, pastor of the First Evangelical United Brethern Church of Lima and a grandson of Mrs. Betts, read the scripture, reading the Twenty-third Psalm and the 14th chapter of John, verses 1-3 and 15-19. Interment was in Oaklawn Cemetery at Tiro.
Serving as pallbearers were Walter Gardner, of Akron; Edward Taylor, of Rittman, Ohio; Alden Betts, U. S. Air Force, Winthrop, Massachusetts; Ernest Rhine, of Galion, Ohio; Kenneth Taylor, of Bucyrus, and Vernon Graham, of Shelby, Ohio. Calling hours were observed at the Barkdull Funeral Home, Shelby.
Friends attending the services from a distance were from Akron, Wadsworth, Cuyahoga Falls, Topeka, Indiana, Columbus, Cambridge, New Concord, Old Washington, Barnesville, Woodsfield, Summerfield, Lewisville, Revenna, Mansfield, Mt. Gilead, Galion, Lima, Crestline, Canton and Massillon.
 

 

March 16. 1961X

WEDDING

Kahrig-Nicholes

Source: Monroe County Beacon

 

The wedding of Miss Sylvia Lucille Nicholes, daughter of Mrs. Virginia Nicholes, of Quaker City and Donald Lee Kahrig, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ben Kahrig, of Route 1, Salesville, was solemnized Saturday afternoon, March 11, at the home of Rev. Francis Smith, in Bethesda.

Attendants of the couple were Miss Wanda Ann Johnson, of Quaker City, close friend of the bride, and Willis Nicholes, of Mt. Olivett, brother of the bride.

The new Mrs. Kahrig graduated from Quaker City High School in 1960. Mr. Kahrig is a 1958 graduate of Quaker City High School. He is employed by Bundy Motor Sales in Quaker City.

They will reside in Salesville.

Mrs. Nicholes and her family entertained with a dinner in their honor on Saturday evening the following guests: Mrs. Ben Kahrig, Jan and Judy Kahrig, Mr. and Mrs. Ernest Roe Jr., and family, of Salesville Route 1; Mr. and Mrs. Willis Nicholes and daughter of Mt. Olivett, and Miss Wanda Johnson of Quaker City.

 

 

 
1961 OOOOO
BREEDEN, Henry C.
Source: probably from Zanesville paper
Henry C. BREEDEN,84, of Dresden died at 4:10 p.m. Tuesday (April 18, 1961) at his home of an apparent heart attack. He had been in ill health for one year and seriously ill since Christmas.
Mr Breeden retired in 1955 as a stationary engineer with the C. Findeiss Sons Company.
He was born April 28, 1876, in Monroe County, the son of Richard and Hannah DAILY BREEDEN. His wife, Lucy Pearl Breeden, died June 24, 1948.
Surviving are five daughters, Mrs. Vera STROUD of Byesville, Mrs. Elsie VEGH of Canton, Mrs. Eva McCOY of Dresden, Mrs. Velva BIRKHIMER of Dresden, and Mrs. Wilma JENNINGS of Coshocton; one son, Arnold R. of Lima; 22 grandchildren; 21 great-grandchildren; one brother, Joe BREEDEN of Byesville and one sister, Mres. Lulu Belle LARRICK of Byesville. One daughter, two brothers, two sisters and two grandsons are deceased.
 
Services will be held at 2 p.m. Friday at the Dresden Chapel of the Baughman and Sons Funeral Home with Rev. C. Driftmyer officiating. Burial will be in Dresden Cemetery.
 
Friends may call at the funeral home after 7 p.m. today.
 
1961
Mrs. Clara Stewart Clark, 81, of 813 Fourth Street, New Martinsville, W. Va., died Wednesday afternoon, March 29, 1961, at Wetzel County Hospital, New Martinsville.  She was born in Monroe County, Ohio on August 15, 1879, the daughter of James D. and Eliza Clark Stewart. Her husband, John Thomas Clark, died in 1943.  Surviving are two sons, John Clark of New Martinsville and Henry Clark of Conneaut, one daughter Mrs. Elizabeth Grimm of New Martinsville, four grandchildren, brother John Stewart of Pine Grove, W. Va., and two sisters, Mrs. Laura Slider of Lake Milton, Ohio, and Mrs. J. C. Farr of Louisville, Ohio.  Services were held in the Iams Funeral Home at New Martinsville, Saturday morning at 11:00 oclock with the Rev. W. H. Sliter officiating.  Interment was in the Greenlawn Memorial Park, New Martinsville.

MARRIAGE
Names: Mr. Earl Anderson
and Miss Dorothy Tucker
Source: The Monroe County Beacon
Issue: Woodsfield, Ohio, April 1961
Collection of Wilda Heft Bartenschlag
On Saturday, April 22, 1961, Miss Dorothy Tucker, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Tucker, Woodsfield, Route 4, was united in marriage with Earl Anderson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Fred Anderson, Lewisville, Ohio, Route 1.
Minister J. V. A. Traylor performed the double-ring ceremony at seven oclock in the afternoon at his home on Eastern avenue, Woodsfield.
The bride chose for her wedding a green taffeta street-length dress with which she wore matching accessories. Her corsage was of yellow carnations.
Her bridesmaid, Mrs. Dale Kilburn, wore a brown suit with which she wore white accessories. Her corsage was also of yellow carnations.
Serving Mr. Anderson as best man was Dale Kilburn.
Mrs. Anderson graduated from Green Local high school, Laings, Ohio, class of 1954 and Mr. Anderson graduated from Lewisville high school, class of 1956.
The newlyweds are now at home to their friends at the William Tucker home on Woodsfield, route 4.

DEATH
Name: David H. Weber
Source: The Monroe County Beacon
Issue: Woodsfield, Ohio, May 1961
Collection of Zelda Weber Betts
David H. Weber, 83, of Lewisville, Ohio Route 1, died on Thursday morning, May 18, 1961, at one oclock at his home after a several weeks illness.
He was born September 8, 1877, near Lewisville, the son of Christian and Civilla Koehler Weber. He was a retired farmer and a member of the Buchanan Presbyterian Church.
Surviving are his widow, Clara Yoho Weber, of the home; six sons, Raymond Weber, of Zanesville, Ohio; Floyd Weber of Lewisville, Route 2; Willard Weber, of Lewisville, Route 1; Irvin Weber, of Brice; Lawrence Weber, of Newark, Ohio; and Earl Weber, of Alexander; three daughters, Mrs. Viola Winland, of Barnesville, Ohio; Mrs. Laura Fisher and Mrs. Zelda Betts, of Lewisville, Route 2; twenty-three grandchildren and nine great grandchildren.
Funeral services were held in the Buchanan Presbyterian Church Sunday afternoon at two oclock, with the Reverend Lester Evans, of Cambridge, Ohio, officiating. Interment was in the Buchanan cemetery with Bauer and Turner Funeral Home, Woodsfield, in charge.

July 1961OOOOOO
Richard H. Betts, son of Charles Curtis Betts and Ellen Morgan
Richard H. Betts
Barnesville-Richard H. Betts, 66, of 216 N. Broadway, died Monday
morning in Cambridge following a long illness.
A former Barnesville businessman, he was born Dec. 29, 1894 at
Batesville, the son of Curtis and Ellen Morgan Betts. He was a member of the
Methodist Church in Quaker City, the Masonic Lodge of Quaker City and the
Elks Lodge of Barnesville.
Mr. Betts leaves his widow, the former Margaret Gibson; a daughter,
Mrs. Lucian Foglesong of Cambridge; a son Gibson Betts of Barnesville; a
sister, Mrs. Ernest Moore of Quaker City; a brother, Ralph Betts of
Barnesville and four grandchildren.
Funeral services will be conducted Wednesday at 2:30 p.m. (DST) at
Campbell Funeral Home by Rev. Fred Shiltz. Burial will be in Friends
Cemetery, Quaker City.
Friends may call at the funeral home after 11 a.m. Tuesday.
[Source: shared by Evelena Brown; dated July 10, 1961]
Richard H. Betts, son of C.C. Betts and Ella Morgan
Richard H. Betts
Barnesville-Richard H. Betts, 66, of 216 North Broadway died early
Monday morning in a Cambridge hospital after a long illness. He was a
retired poultry dealer.
A son of Curtis and Ellen Betts, he was born Dec. 19, 1894, in
Batesville and married Margaret Gibson Dec. 4, 1915, who survives.
Mr. Betts also operated a meat market and restaurant in Barnesville for
several years. He was a member of Quaker City Methodist Church, Quaker City
Masonic and Barnesville Elks Lodge.
In addition to his widow, he leaves a son, Gibson of Barnesville; a
daughter, Mrs. Lucian Foglesong of Cambridge; four grandchildren; a brother,
Ralph Betts of Barnesville, and a sister, Mrs. Ernest Moore of Quaker City.
Friends may call after 11 am Tuesday at Campbell Funeral Home here.
Services will be held in the funeral home at 2:30 p.m.
[Source: shared by Evelena Brown; dated July 10, 1961]

 

July 27, 1961X

ENGAGEMENT

Schumacher-Heft

Source: Monroe Co. Beacon

Mr. and Mrs. Stanley J. Heft of the Lewisville Road, announce the engagement of their only daughter, Carol, to Mr. Richard E. Schumacher, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred A. Schumacher of 420 Eastern Avenue.

The bride-elect is a graduate of Woodsfield High School and is presently employed as a receptionist-secretary for W. E. Hutton & Company in Columbus.

Mr. Schumacher, also a graduate of Woodsfield High School, was employed with the Federal Bureau of Investigation in Washington, D. C., while attending college. In 1960 he received his Bachelor of Commercial Science in Financial Administration Degree from Strayer College, Washington, D. C. He is presently employed as an accountant with Public Employees State Retirement System in Columbus.

The wedding will be an event of September 4, 1961 in St. Sylvester's Church. The custom of "Open Church" will be observed.

DEATH
Source: The Monroe County Beacon, dated, August 10, 1961
MRS. PHOEBE A. HIGHMAN DIES WEDNESDAY MORNING
Provided by Lena Kahrig Pettit
Mrs. Phoebe Ann Highman, 89, widow of Abner Highman, died Wednesday morning, August 9, 1961, at four oclock, at her home on Woodsfield, Route 2. She had been in failing health for several months.
She was born July 7, 1872, the daughter of the late George and Nancy Jane Edington Drake, of Woodsfield, Route 2.
Mrs. Highman was a member of the Connor Ridge Methodist Church.
Surviving are two daughters, Mrs. Alonzo Cline and Mrs. David Williams of Woodsfield, Route 2; four sons, Otto Highman, of the home; Alonzo Highman, of Ashland; Jay Highman, of Lewisville, Route 2, and David Highman, of Woodsfield, Route 2; twenty-five grandchildren; fifth-eight great grandchildren; three sisters and two brothers. her husband, Abner Highman preceded her in death several years ago.
Friends will be received at the Bauer and Turner Funeral Home after one oclock Thursday afternoon.
Funeral services will be held in their chapel on Saturday afternoon at two oclock D. S. T., with Reverend Milford Carey, of Stafford, officiating. Interment will be in the Connor Ridge Cemetery.
 

December 28, 1961

DEATH

George H. Christman

Source: Monroe County Beacon

 

George H. Christman, age 84, a retired farmer, died early Tuesday morning, December 26th, at his home in Woodsfield.

A son of the late Jacob and Fredericka Pfalzgraf Christman, he was born July 2, 1877, near Lewisville. His wife, Edna Baker Christman died November 25, 1958.

Surviving are two daughters, Mrs. Dorothy Fischer of Grosse Pointe Woods, Michigan, and Mrs. Helen Christy, of Marion; two sons Wilfred Christman of Ann Arbor, Michigan and Edward Christman, of Southgate, Michigan; seven grandchildren and two great grandchildren; also four sisters, Miss Tillie Christman, Miss Louise Christman, Mrs. Anna Weber and Mrs. Minnie Heft, all of Lewisville.

Friends are being received at the Bauer and Turner Funeral Home.

Services will be held in their chapel Friday afternoon at two o'clock with Rev. George Corbitt officiating. Interment will be in the Friendship Cemetery at Lewisville

DEATH
Name: Leslie Leroy Long
Source: The Monroe County Beacon,
Woodsfield, Ohio, dated, February 15, 1962
 
Leslie Leroy Long, 59, of near Batesville, Ohio died unexpectedly on Wednesday evening, February 7, 1962, at 6:30 oclock, apparently of a heart attack while driving his truck near his home.
A native of Noble County, he was born October 24, 1902, a son of Carol Francis Long and the late Etta Brownfield Long. He was a farmer.
Surviving are his father who resides near Batesville; two sons, William Leslie Long of Quaker City, Route 4 and Darrell Lynn Long, of Batesville; two daughters, Mrs. Dorothy Pauline Atkinson, of Quaker City, Route 1 and Miss Mona Sue Block of Batesville; a brother, Wayne Long, of Quaker City, Route 1; one sister, Mrs. Opal Carpenter of Summerfield, and four grandchildren. A brother and a sister preceded him in death.
Funeral services were held at the Eberle Funeral Home in Quaker City on Saturday afternoon at 1:30 oclock with the Reverend Herman Gray officiating. Interment was in the Batesville Cemetery, Batesville, Ohio.
 
1962
Edmond L. Highman
Source:  The Monroe County Beacon, March 2, 1962
   Edmond L. Highman, 53, of Ashland, Route 2, Ohio, formerly of Woodsfield, died at his home Thursday Morning, March 1, 1962, at 6:30 o'clock, following a lingering illness.
   A son of Oscar and Myrtle Willison Highman, he was born at Graysville, on June 20, 1929.
   Surviving are his wife, Olive; his mother, Mrs. Oscar Highman, of Polk, Ohio; one son, Ramon Highman, of Ashland, Route 2; two grandchildren; one sister, Mrs. Evelyn Cline, of Polk, and two brothers, Chester Highman, of Ashland, and Harold Highman, of Mt. Vernon.

July 19, 1962X

MARRIAGE

Robinson-Christman

Source: Monroe County Beacon

 

Sunday afternoon, June tenth, at half after two, a closed church ceremony was performed in the Stafford Methodist Church at Stafford. Miss Barbara Robinson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Robinson, of Stafford, became the bride of Larry Christman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Howard Christman of near Lewisville.

The double ring ceremony was performed by Rev. Milford Carey. Tall vases of pink and white gladioli and potted palms decorated the sanctuary.

Mrs. William Mallett, organist, played nuptial selections preceding the wedding.

Given in marriage by her father, the bride wore a self-designed gown of white satin in princess style with a sprinkling of seed pearls at the neckline. Her shoulder length veil of silk illusion, draped from a small satin pillbox. She wore matching long white gloves and carried a bouquet of pink roses and white snaps with pink satin streamers tied in lover's knots.

Mrs. Tom Robinson, sister-in-law of the bride, was matron of honor. She wore a pale blue nylon dress with a matching headpiece.

Loren Christman, cousin of the bridegroom, was best man, and ushers were Larry and Gary Wehr, also cousins of the bridegroom.

Immediately following the ceremony a reception was held on the church lawn. Later the couple left for a wedding trip through the southern states.

The new Mrs. Christman was graduated from Skyvue High School and Valley Beauty School in Marietta. She is now employed at Florence's Beauty Salon in Marietta.

Mr. Christman, a graduate of Skyvue High School also is a senior at Marietta College.

1963
October 18, 1963
Wilson, Gilber Haven
Provided by Betty Lendon Matson
Gilber Haven Wilson was born April 5, 1875 in Monroe Co. Ohio. He was the son of George Matson Wilson and Mary Belle Young. He died in California in 1963.
---------------------------------------------
Gilbert Haven Wilson, a former Claremont resident who sang before 5 presidents of the United States, died in San Bernardino hospital Friday evening, October 18 (1963). Private graveside services were held Wednesday, October 23 in Oak Park Cemetery.
Mr. Wilson moved from Claremont to Twenty-Nine Palms about 1950. While living in this city, he went to the nations capital to officiate in the 1940 drawing of draft numbers. He was the composer of Long Live America and of The Firefall Song and sang the latter composition for the first time at Camp Curry, Yosemite.
On July 4, 1918, Mr. Wilson led the singing on the plaza of the capitol in Washington, D.C. Participating were President Woodrow Wilson, his cabinet, the Congress and about 50,000 on-lookers. Mr. Wilson also sang before Presidents Theodore Roosevelt, William Howard Taft, Calvin Coolidge, and Franklin Delano Roosevelt.
One of Mr. Wilsons friends was Josephus Daniels, who was Secretary of the Navy during World War I, when Franklin D. Roosevelt was assistant secretary.
In World War I days, the musician was in the United States Marine Corps as musical director and song leader. On convoy battleships anchored at secret base at Norfolk, VA., he inaugurated the custom of community singing on dreadnaughts.
Mr. Wilson sang in opera and gave many concerts in New York City for 15 years preceding World War I.
George C. S. Benson officiated at gravesite services for Mr. Wilson. Interment was made by the side of his wife, Mrs. Marjorie H. Wilson, who died in 1951.
More on Gilbert Haven Wilson:
First Wife Ellen Bradley Mays Married December 28, 1898 in Lancaster, KY
Two sons to this marriage: George Nelson Wilson b. 1902
And Lafon Mays Wilson b. 1905

January 2, 1964XXXXX

MARRIAGE

Morris-Crum

Source: Beacon

 

Miss Betty Lou Morris, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ermie Morris of Woodsfield, Route 3, and John F. Crum, son of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond J Crum, of Summerfield Route 1, were united in marriage on Saturday, October nineteenth, at St. Michael's Catholic Church in Carlisle. The Rev. Rudolph Wargo officiated at the double ring ceremony at half after nine o'clock in the morning.

The altar was decorated with vases of pink mums. Miss Euncie Horton was organist.

The bride, given in marriage by her father, wore a floor-length gown of Chantilly Lace. It was designed with a sabrina neckline and long sleeves tapering to points over her hands. The bouffant skirt was made of tiers of Chantilly Lace and net. A crown of pearls and organza petals held her elbow length veil of French silk illusion. Her only jewelry was strand of pears, a gift of the bridegroom, and her bridal bouquet was of pink and white roses with ivy, and a crystal rosary.

She carried out the tradition of something old, new, borrowed and blue and a penny in her shoe.

Mrs. Glen Burkhart, sister of the bridegroom, was matron of honor. She wore a dress of pink taffeta brocade with matching circular veil, and carried a colonial bouquet of pink and white carnations.

Glen Burkhart served Mr. Crum as best man.

The bride's mother chose a navy blue dress with black accessories. Mrs. Crum was attired in a blue and white silk dress with black accessories. Each wore a corsage of white carnations.

Following the ceremony, a dinner for the immediate family was served at the home of the bride's parents.

A shower was held in the evening, for one hundred and fifty guests at the home of the bride. Centering the bride's table was a four-tiered wedding cake decorated with pink roses and topped with a miniature bride and groom.

Hostesses at the dinner and shower were Mrs. Lela Christman, Miss Kay Christman, Miss Merle Crawford and Mrs. Gertrude Kahrig, all relatives of the bride.

The bride is a graduate of Skyvue High School Stafford. She is employed by Highlights for Children at Columbus, Ohio,

Mr. Crum is a graduate of Summerfield High School and is employed by Westinghouse at Columbus.

Leaving for her honeymoon, the bride wore a navy and white suit with black accessories and a corsage from her bridal bouquet.

Mr. and Mrs. Crum are now living t 232 West Ninth Avenue, Columbus.

Weber, of Lewisville, exchanged vows of marriage on Friday, March sixth at eight-thirty o'clock in the evening, in the First Baptist Church, North Street, Caldwell. Pastor Roy Wikander officiated for the double ring ceremony in the presence of the immediate families.

The bride wore a street length white brocade sheath with long sleeves and high neckline. Her veil was shoulder length. A red rosebud corsage complemented her ensemble.

Mrs. Larry Anderson, a friend of the bride, was matron of honor. She wore an orange sheath with a white mum corsage.

Charles D. Whealdon, brother of the bride, was best man.

Mrs. Whealdon chose a brown sheath with gold accessories and a yellow mum corsage was pinned to her shoulder line. Mrs. Weber wore beige with white accessories and her corsage was white mums.

Immediately following the ceremony a reception for twenty guests was held in the home of the bride's mother. Aides were Mrs. Larry Anderson and Mr. C. D. Whealdon.

The bride is a graduate of Caldwell High School. Mr. Weber graduated from Skyvue High School, Stafford and is employed with the Baker Company, Caldwell.

Since returning from a wedding trip the couple is residing on Cumberland Street, in Caldwell.

Out of town guests were from Lewisville, Marietta and Columbus.

DEATH

Rachel Christman

Source: Beacon

Rachel Christman, daughter of Louis and Christina Mecklin Matz was born April 1, 1873 and departed this life March 6, 1965, being 91 years, eleven months, and four days of age.

Baptized in infancy, she was confirmed in 1887 at St. John's Middle Church and remained a member all her life, the Church now being Trinity United Church of Christ.

Preceding her in death was her husband, Jacob J. Christman, whom she married March 13, 1894.

To this union were born eight children; Mrs. Arthur (Bertha) Neuhardt, Mrs. Vernon (Gladys) Reich, Mrs. Okey (Zelda) Rubel, Mrs. Harold (Edna) Young, all of the Lewisville Community; Mrs. Gilbert (Oneda) Ludwig, of Woodsfield; Mrs. Vernon (Ruby) Mann, of Jerusalem; and Elmer Christman, of Apple Creek, Ohio. One son died in infancy.

A brother William F. Matz, of Woodsfield also is living.

The thirty-one grandchildren and sixty great grandchildren were a joy and consolation to Mrs. Christman. One granddaughter and three great grandsons preceded her in death.

Mrs. Christman was one of twelve children. Four brothers, Phillip, Christopher, Louis E. and Herman Matz; and six sisters, Mrs. Fred (Amelia) Neuhart, Mrs. John (Elizabeth) Hines, Mrs. Chris (Louise) Leibfarth, Mrs. Amiel (Mary) Faber, Mrs. Charles (Elma) Legg, and Mrs. George L. June 24, 1965

MARRIAGE

Pfalzgraf-Dehlquist

Source: Beacon

The courtyard of the Methodist Theological Seminary in Delaware, Ohio, was the setting on Monday, June fourteenth, for the marriage of Miss Charlene Faye Pfalzgraf and Mr. Paul Anders Dehlquist.

The Rev. Alfred P. Beale officiated at the double ring ceremony at 12:30 p.m.

The bride is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Raymond Pfalzgraf of Route 1, Clarington, Ohio. Mr. Dehlquist's parents are Mr. and Mrs. Harold P. Dehlquist, of Bethlehem, Connecticut, and Honolulu, Hawaii.

The bride, given in marriage by her father, wore a gown of white swiss organdy and sabrina neckline, and redingote design edged in swiss embroidered organdy. The soft fullness at the waistline extended into a brush train. The three- tiered crown of sheer and tiny crystals held her shoulder length English illusion veil. The bride carried a white Bible with a bouquet of orchids.

Attending the bride was her sister, Miss Barbara Ann Pfalzgraf, as maid of honor. She wore a floor length gown of petal pink silk linen with midriff trim of embroidered flowers, square neck and brief sleeves. A tailored bow finished the back interest. The headpiece, of matching color, was a pleated pillbox with a circle veil. She also carried a bouquet of orchids.

Mr. David Hegans, of Columbus, served as best man.

Following the ceremony a wedding dinner was served at Green Meadows Country Inn.

The bride is a graduate of the Ohio State University, Columbus, where she also received her Master's Degree in Sociology. She is a teacher of History in the Jefferson Local School District in West Jefferson, Ohio.

Mr. Dehlquist is a graduate of the Punahou School of Honolulu, and received his Bachelor of Arts Degree from Yale University. He is currently pursuing graduate studies and teaching at the Ohio State University.

Following a wedding trip though the South, the couple will spend the summer in Vermont and return, in August, to reside at their country home near Marysville, Ohio.

1965X
Marriage
Names: Mr. Larry E. Reich
and Miss Glenda J. Christman
Source: The Monroe County Beacon
Issue: Woodsfield, Ohio August 1965
Collection of Wilda Heft Bartenschlag
The small country Church, formerly known as Middle Church of the Lewisville Trinity United Church of Christ, was the setting on Saturday, August 28, 1965, for the marriage of Miss Glenda J. Christman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Eldon Christman, of Lewisville, Ohio and Larry E. Reich, son of Mr. and Mrs. Vernon Reich, also of Lewisville.
A former pastor of the young, Reverend George Varns, now of Edwardsport, Indiana, performed double ring ceremony. He was assisted by the Reverend Donald Stump, present pastor of Lewisville Trinity Church.
Organ selections by Mrs. Amos DeWitt and vocal selections by Miss Kay Young preceded the wedding.
The bride was given in marriage by her father. She wore a floor-length gown of satin and lace which she designed and made. Her only jewelry was a necklace which had been worn by her Grandmother Christman on her wedding day. She carried a bridal bouquet of white mums and ivy.
The matron of honor was Mrs. Larry Hamilton, of Lebanon, Ohio. She wore a floor-length gown of mint green taffeta and carried a bouquet of yellow mums.
Larry Hamilton served Mr. Reich as best man. Ushers were Ronald Christman and Forest Frank and Vernie Reich was acolyte.
Over two hundred guests were served at a reception at Fellowship Hall following the ceremony. Mrs. Freeman Kilburn and Mrs. Forest Frank were co- chairman of the reception. Miss Brenda Waligura, of Adena, and Miss Anne Wells, of Dayton, Ohio, former roommates of the bride, and Shirley Seebach, cousin of the bride, served at the reception table which was centered with a three-tiered wedding cake that had been baked and decorated by the brides aunt, Mrs. Bill Seebach. Connie Seebach and Roselyn Reich greeted and seated the guests. Mrs. Dale Yontz presided at the guest book.
The brides mother wore a black and brown eyelet embroidered sheath dress with black accessories and a corsage of yellow miniature mums. The bridegrooms mother wore a blue crepe two-piece dress with black and white miniature mums.
For going away the bride changed to a toast colored knit dress with black accessories. The couple motored to Athens, Ohio. A welcome home reception planned by Athens friends surprised the couple when they arrived at their newly furnished apartment at 143 1/2 N. Lancaster Street.
The new Mrs. Reich is a senior at Ohio University, majoring in Home Economics and Education. She is a member of Phi Upsilon Omicron, honorary fraternity of Home Economics Majors.
Mr. Reich recently graduated from Ohio University with a major in Science in Education. He is now teaching in the high school at Nelsonville, Ohio.
On Friday evening, Mr. and Mrs. Vernon Reich were hosts for the rehearsal dinner attended by the wedding party and the immediate families of the couple.

December 16, 1965X

MARRIAGE

Thomas-Christman

Source: Monroe County Beacon

 

Miss Rosalie Thomas, daughter of Mrs. Wilbur Thomas, of the Moose Ridge Road, Woodsfield and the late Mr. Thomas, and Mr. Charles Edward Christman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Roy Christman, of Oaklawn Avenue, Woodsfield, were united in marriage on Sunday, November seventh, at two o'clock in the afternoon in St. Paul's United Church of Christ, Woodsfield. The Rev. George R. Corbitt officiated at the double ring ceremony.

Given in marriage by her brother, the bride wore a two piece suit of pink silk. She carried a Bible topped with a bouquet of white carnations and roses.

Miss Betty Christman, sister of the bridegroom, was matron of honor. She wore a pink two piece dress with black accessories, and carried a bouquet of white tinted carnations.

Mr. Roger Thomas, brother of the bride, served Mr. Chrsitman as best man.

Attending the wedding were Mr. and Mrs. Roy Christman, and family; Mrs. Mildred Thomas; Mr. and Mrs. Paul Christman and family; Roger Christman; Mr. and Mrs. Raymond E. Petty and daughter.

The new Mrs. Christman is a graduate of Woodsfield High School. She is employed at Radson's Supermarket in Woodsfield.

Mr. Christman attended Woodsfield Schools, and is employed by his father at the Christman Supply Company, in Woodsfield.

The couple is now residing on Moose Ridge Road, Woodsfield.

Obituary: 23 Dec 1965 Jeffersonian newspaper

Quaker City - Mrs Estella Groves, 83, Salesville, R.D. 1, was found dead in bed about 6 p.m. Wednesday at her home. She apparently died in her sleep Wednesday morning from natural causes.

She was born in Noble County, Aug 14, 1882, the daughter of Roland J and Nancy Wilson Danford, and was a member of the Bates Hill Church of Christ.

She married John Groves in June 1903 and he died Dec 25, 1953.

She leaves two sons, Donald Groves, Kansas City, Mo, and Walter of Portsmouth; five daughters, Mrs Beulah Smith, Mrs Louie Tidyman, Mrs Beatrice Klein, Mrs Annie Kight, all of Akron and Mrs Bernice Weaver, near Salesville; 15 grandchildren, 11 great-gradchildren; two sisters, Mrs Mary Britton near Senecaville and Mrs Dulcie Stallings, near Salesville.

Friends may call at the Eberle Funeral Home from 2 to 4 and 7 to 9 p.m. Saturday.

Services will be at 1 p.m. Sunday at the funeral home with Evangelist McKinley Bates officiating. Burial will be in Friends Cemetery.

DEATH
Name: Mrs. Clara L. Christman, nee Claus
Source: The Monroe County Beacon
Woodsfield, Ohio, February, 1966
Collection of Mary Eva Betts Christman
Mrs. Clara L. Christman, daughter of Fred and Caroline Haffner Claus, was born February 17, 1898, near Lewisville, Ohio, and departed from this life February 12, 1966, at Doctors Hospital, Massillon, Ohio, being 67 years, 11 months and 26 days of age.
She was united in marriage with Elmer G. Christman on April 29, 1924. To this union three sons and one daughter was born.
Surviving are her husband, Elmer Christman, of Apple Creek, Ohio; two sons, Melvin Christman, of Apple Creek, and LaVern Christman, of Columbus, Ohio; one daughter, Carolyn, of Apple Creek; one sister, Mrs. Anna Christman, of Barnesville, Ohio; two brothers, Edwin Claus, of Smithland, Iowa, and Gilbert Claus, of Lewisville, Ohio, and one uncle, John Haffner, of Harrietsville, Ohio.
An infant son, her parents, four brothers and one sister preceded her in death.
Mrs. Christman was confirmed at an early age in the United Church of Christ (Middle Church). She spent most of her life in Lewisville vicinity, moving to Apple Creek, Ohio in 1950 where she remained until her death. The last two years she was a semi-invalid but always had a smile and a kind word for everyone.
The body lay in state on Sunday, February 13 at McIntires Funeral Home, Wooster, Ohio, being transferred on Monday to Brubachs Funeral Home, at Summerfield, Ohio. Services were conducted by the Reverend Donald Stump, on Tuesday, February 15, at the Fellowship Hall, Lewisville, with burial in the St. Johns Middle Church cemetery, near Lewisville.

1966
Elton L. Latta
SOURCE:  September 15, 1966, Canton Repository. Canton, Ohio:
Picture accompanying the article is labeled : ELTON L. LATTA Dies on Chicago Trip
HEART ATTACK TAKES LIFE OF ELTON LATTA----
        Elton L. Latta, 60, of 3145 Landscape Circle NW, died Wednesday night in Chicago.
        Mr. Latta, director of service for the Hercules Engine Division of theHupp Corp., was waiting for a flight back to Canton at O'Hare International Airport in Chicago, when he suffered a heart attack and was pronounced dead on arrival at a Chicago hospital.
        A veteran of 37 years with the company, Mr. Latta had been chief inspector for a number of years and for the last several years was director of service.
        He was a Canton native and graduate of McKinley High School and Mount Union College where he was a member of Phi Kappa Kau [sic--Tau] fraternity.
        He is survived by his widow, Thelma A. Latta; his mother, Mrs. D. W. Latta of Canton; a sister, Miss Jan Edith Latta of Canton, and twobrothers, Donald G. Latta of East Canton, and Vernon J. Latta of Canton.
        Services are being planned for Saturday.  Friends may call Friday 2 to 4 and 7 to 9 p.m. at the Formet and Clevenger Funeral Home.
He was buried in North Lawn Cemetery, Canton, Ohio.

BARNESVILLE William E. Brownfield, 82, of Fairview near here died at 7 a. m. Monday (Oct. 10) at Barnesville Hospital where he had been a patient two weeks.  He was born May 27, 1884, in Monroe County, a son of Stephen and Lena Wells Brownfield.  He was a retired farmer and a member of Fairview Church of Christ.
Surviving are his widow, the former Ella Powell; two sons, Elza of Fairview and Lamont of 350 White Oak avenue; six daughters, Mrs. Harold Davis and Mrs. Lucille Brister of Fairview, Mrs. Rutherford Davis of Belmont, Mrs. L. R. Cunningham of Lore City Route 1, and Mrs. William Bates and Miss Minnie Brownfield of West Lafayette; 38 grandchildren and 17 great grandchildren.

Friends may call after 1 p. m. (EDT) today at Campbell Funeral Home here.  Services will be held at 2 p. m. (EDT) Wednesday at the Church of Christ at Fairview.  Burial will be in Fairview Cemetery.

Elmer D. Bintz

Source: Beacon

 

Elmer D. Bintz, 82, of near Lewisville, died early Tuesday morning, October 11, 1966, in Crestline Memorial Hospital. He had been in ill health for some time.

Mr. Bintz, a retired farmer, was born March 9, 1884, near Lewisville, the son of the late George and Anna Bintz. He was a member of the Lewisville Methodist Church.

His first wife, Anna Pfalzgraf Bintz died in 1919. In 1931 he married Pauline Pfalzgraf, who died in 1965.

Surviving are five daughters, Miss Sophis Bintz, of Barnesville; Mrs. Leona Betts, of Barberton; Mrs. Rose Studer, of Mansfield; Mrs. Freda Wichterman of Crestline, and Mrs. Esther Garrett of Galion; four sisters, Mrs. Freda Clegg of Barnesville; Mrs. Esta Taylor and Mrs. Clara Hines of Bucyrus, and Mrs. Viola Christman, of Quaker City; eleven grandchildren and three great grandchildren.

Friends are being received at the Bauer and Turner Funeral Home. Funeral services will be held on Friday afternoon at two o'clock in the funeral chapel. Burial will be in the Friendship Cemetery, Lewisville.

December 15, 1966

MARRIAGE

Brooks-Betts

Source: Monroe County Beacon

 

Miss Lois Marie Brooks, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Brooks, of Woodsfield, became the bride of Mr. Ronald E. Betts, son of Mr. and Mrs. E. W. Betts, of Lewisville on Saturday, November twenty-sixth, at one o'clock in the afternoon in St. Sylvester's Catholic Church.

The Very Rev. Msgr. Robert A. Brown officiated at the double ring ceremony before an altar decorated with yellow chrysanthemums and white pomps.

The bride, given in marriage by her father, wore a floor length gown of white Satin peau styled with a bateau neckline and long sleeves accented by bell shaped lace cuffs studded with seed pearls. The semi straight skirt fell into folds forming a short chapel train. Her veil of silk illusion was attached to a crown of pearls and lace. She carried a white satin and lace Bible topped with white pomps and stephanotis.

The matron of honor was Mrs. Russell Betts, sister-in-law of the bridegroom. She was attired in a floor length gown of limoges blue, styled with a bateau neckline and elbow length sleeves. The straight skirt was draped with a wateau accented by a self-bow. She carried a bouquet of yellow and white pomps. Bridesmaids were Misses Clara Mehler and Lucy Kuhn, friends of the bride. Their gowns of poudre blue were identical in style to that of the matron of honor, and their bouquets were of yellow pomps.

Mr. Russell Betts served his brother as best man. Ushers were Mr. Darrell Betts, brother of the bridegroom, and Mr. Merlin Fisher, cousin of the bridegroom.

Miss Penny Piatt, friend of the bride, presided at the guest book.

A reception was held immediately following the ceremony, in the church hall. Hostesses were Mrs. Helen Stack, of Clarington, and Mrs. Florence Schumacher of Woodsfield.

The new Mrs. Betts is a 1964 graduate of Woodsfield High School and has been employed as secretary at L.G.A.M. Manufacturing Co. in Woodsfield since that time.

Mr. Betts, a 1963 graduate of Skyvue High School at Stafford, Ohio is presently employed with Anchor Fastener, Inc., at Bedford, Ohio.

The bride will reside with her parents until her husband has completed a six months training period with the National Guard.

MARRIAGE
Names: Mr. Byron L. Morris
and Miss Myra Jean Claus
Source: The Monroe County Beacon
Issue: Woodsfield, Ohio, July 15, 1967
Collection of Mary Eva Betts Christman
Miss Myra Jean Claus, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lewis Claus, of Jerusalem, Ohio and Mr. Byron L. Morris, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ermie Morris of Woodsfield, Route 3, were united in marriage on Saturday evening, July fifteenth, 1967. The vows were exchanged at 6:15 p.m. at the home of Minister J. V. A. Traylor who performed the double ring ceremony.
Attending the wedding were the couples parents and the brides grandmother, Mrs. Laura Claus; also, Mrs. David Lallathin, of Akron, Ohio, sister of the bridegroom, and Mrs. Robert Morris, of Barnesville, Ohio.
Mrs. Floyd Crawford, sister of the bride, was matron of honor.
Mr. Robert Morris, of Barnesville, served his brother as best man.
Following the ceremony a reception was held at the Beallsville High school, with over one hundred friends and relatives attending.
Serving as hostesses were the brides sisters, Mrs. Floyd Crawford and Miss Darlene Claus; and Miss Evelyn Kress, Mrs. Clara Schumacher and Miss Sharon Decker.
The bride is a graduate of Beallsville High School, Beallsville, Ohio and the School of Cosmetology at Cambridge, Ohio. She is employed at Akron, Ohio.
Mr. Morris is a graduate of Skyvue High school and is employed by the Pepsi Cola Company in Akron. He served two years in the U. S. Army, one year being spent in Korea.
Mr. and Mrs. Morris are making their home at 407 East Archwood, Akron, Ohio.

DEATH

George L. Christman

Source: Monroe County Beacon

 

George L. Christman, 89, of near Monroefield, Lewisville Route 1, died Friday afternoon, August 25 1967, at two o'clock at his home following an illness.

He was born in Monroe County, March 29, 1878, a son of Philip and Rosanna Pfalzgraf Christman.

Mr. Christman was a member of the Trinity United Church of Christ, Lewisville.

Surviving are five daughters, Mrs. Sylvester (Elma) Burkhart, Mrs. Gilbert (Esther) Claus, Mrs. Alfred (Gertrude) Kahrig, Mrs. George (Laura) Kahrig and Mrs. Wilbert (Beryl) Claus, all of Lewisville Route 1; three sons, Arthur Christman, of Wooster; Clarence Christman of Apple Creek, and Paul Christman of Cambridge; 27 grandchildren and 3 great grandchildren. Ralph R. Betts, son of C.C. Betts and Ella Morgan
Services At Barnesville For Ralph R. Betts
A Batesville native, Ralph R. Betts, 63, Barnesville, died Sunday
morning at Barnesville Hospital. He had been in failing health for some
time.
A son of Curt C. and Ella Morgan Betts, he was born at Batesville,
Noble County June 20, 1904. He had lived in Barnesville more than 30 years,
where he had been engaged in the Moore and Betts meat business and later
operated the Buick auto agency.
Mr. Betts was a member of the First Presbyterian Church, Elks Lodge No.
1699, the Seneca Sportsmen Club, and a past president of the Barnesville
Chamber of Commerce. He had also served as inspector for the Bureau of
Motor Vehicles for a number of years.
Surviving are his wife, Lucille Betts of the home; one son, Robert of
Newark; three grandchildren; and one sister, Mrs. Ernest Moore or Quaker
City.
Elks services were conducted at the Campbell Funeral Home Tuesday
evening, with the funeral held the following afternoon followed by burial in
Crestview Cemetery, Barnesville. Rev. Roy Hillard officiated.
[Source: Shared by Evelena Brown; dated October 22, 1967]

(Phillip W. Kahrig was born on 06 May 1890 in Lewisville, Monroe Co., OH. He died on 18 Nov 1967 in Woodsfield, Monroe Co., OH.) Source: The Zanesville Times Recorder on 20 Nov 1967:
LEWISVILLE MAN LEAVES 126 SURVIVORS
WOODSFIELD -- Phillip W. Kahrig, 87 year old retired Monroe County farmer, died at his home near Lewisville at 9 a.m. Saturday [Nov 18] leaving 126 survivors. He had been in declining health. Mr. Kahrig was a member of the United Church of Christ near Lewisville. He was born May 6, 1890, a son of Ludwig and Catherine Getler Kahrig.
Surviving are his widow, Louise Pfalzgraf Kahrig, six sons, Lawrence, Alfred, and George, all of Lewisville Route 1, Edwin of Marietta, and Benjamin and Homer of Salesville; four daughters, Mrs. Alva (Pauline) Christman of Calais, Mrs. Marie Broooks of Mantua, Mrs. Clem (Sophia) Reischman of Barnseville, and Mrs. Robert (Minnie) Walters of Marietta, a brother, Fred, of Woodsfield; and 51 grandchildren and 63 great grandchildren.
The body is at the Bauer-Turner Funeral Home where services will be held at 1 p.m. Tuesday. Rev. Wilmer Grunwald will officiate. Burial will be in Middle Church Cemetery near Lewisville. Friends may call at the funeral home.
 
1967

November 1967

DEATHS

Scotty G. Long / Brenda K. Hannahs

 

Two area residents were found dead late Saturday morning in a car parked in a field off Route 513, three miles south of Batesville.

The two, Scotty G. Long, 25, of near Batesville and Mrs. Brenda Kay Hannahs, 21, of 235 Henderson Street, Barnesville, died of carbon monoxide poisoning, Dr. Sherman Smith, Noble County Coroner said.

Noble County Sheriff Ralph Gibbs, who investigated said the bodies were found a bout 10 a.m. by Roy Brownsfield, a Batesville area farmer.

Dr. Smith said both had been dead six to eight hours. He ruled the deaths accidental.

Long's body was removed to the Eberle Funeral Home, Quaker City, and the body of Mrs. Hannahs was taken to the Brubach Funeral Home, Summerfield.

Born April 18, 1942, in Noble County, Long was a son of Wayne and Edna Christman Long, near Batesville. He served overseas with the U.S. Army from May 6, 1964, to April 7, 1966, and was a member of the Moose Lodge.

Surviving are his parents, a brother and a sister. Another brother is deceased.

Evangelist McKinley Bates conducted funeral services for Long at l:30 p.m. Monday and burial was in Batesville Cemetery.

Funeral services for Mrs. Hannahs were held at one o'clock Tuesday afternoon at the Campbell Funeral Home, in Barnesville, with Rev.Milford E. Carey officiating. Burial was in Holly Memorial Garden, Pleasant Grove.

Born in Barnesville, July 16, 1946, she was a daughter of James Kimbel of Barnesville and the late Virginia Burkhart Kimbel.

Surviving in addition to her father, are her husband, Carl Hannahs; a daughter, Carla Kay of the home; her step-mother, Doris; four sisters, Miss Donna Kimbel, of Mt. Vernon; Mrs. Linda Madison and Miss Susie Kimbel both of Palm Springs, California, and Miss Sharon Kimbel of Quaker City; a half-sister, Malinda Jane Kimbel and a half-brother, James Kimbel, both of Barnesville; two step-sisters; a step-brother; her maternal grandparents, Mr. and Mrs. Clem Burkhart, of Miltonsburg; and her foster mother , Mrs. Rosa Carpenter, of Quaker City.

June 2, 1968X

DEATH

Royden R, Harper

Source: Monroe County Beacon

 

Royden R. Harper, age 78, of 146 Rowmont Road, S. W. Massillon, passed away Wednesday morning, June 26, 1968, in Massillon. He had been in failing health for the past four years.

He was born November 8, 1889, in Monroe County the son of the late James and Mary Beardmore Harper.

Mr. Harper had been a resident of the Canton-Massillon area for the past fifty years. He was a retired carpenter and had been employed by Gibbons and Grable Construction Company.

He was a member of the Lowell United Church of Christ and the Seaman Bible Class.

Surviving are his wife, Sarah Egger Harper; three sons, Virgil S. Harper and Ray C. Harper, both of Canton; James J. Harper of Massillon; two daughters, Mrs. Francis (Vivian) Heft of Lewisville, and Mrs. William (Phyllis) Roudebush of North Canton; two sisters, Mrs. Amelia Neuhardt of Lewisville and Mrs. Stella Carpenter of Fairview; thirteen grandchildren; six great grandchildren.

Funeral services will be held Saturday morning t 10:30 o'clock in the Reed Funeral Home in Canton, with the Rev. L. Meid Becker officiating. Burial will be in Sunset Hill Burial Park, in Canton.

Calling hours at the funeral home will be Friday afternoon from two until four o'clock and in the evening from seven until nine o'clock.

Services Held For Mrs. Emma Long
Funeral services for Mrs. Emma B. Long, 90, former resident of
Batesville and Quaker City, were conducted at 2 p.m. Wednesday at the Eberle
Funeral Home, Quaker City. Rev. Allan Teter, Methodist minister, officiated
and burial followed in Friends cemetery.
Mrs. Long died at 11:30 a.m., Monday, Dec. 9, 1968, at Guernsey Memorial
Hospital, Cambridge, where she had been a patient two days. She had been a
resident at the Nightingale Nursing Home in Cambridge for some time.
She was born July 1, 1878 in Noble County, the daughter of James and
Elizabeth Shuman Betts, and was a member of the Quaker City O.E.S.,
Cambridge Shrine 14, Order of White Shrine of Jerusalem, and Batesville
United Methodist Church. She was a past matron of the local O.E.S. chapter.
Mrs. Long leaves one son, Robert, of Dayton; one sister, Mrs. Eva Carr,
of Cumberland; and one grandson, Rex Long. Her husband, Mentor, who
operated the M.G. Long Hardware store in Batesville, died in 1941. Three
brothers and three sisters are deceased. Mrs. Mable Coultas of Quaker City
is a niece and had close connections with her aunt.
Eastern Star services were held at the funeral home at 8 p.m. Tuesday.
[Source: article shared by Evelena Brown; dated 1968]

Clare S. Wells
Oldest Living Past Master of Masons Dies
Clare S. Wells, 93, of 161 N. Union St., died Friday night at his
residence following a brief illness.
He was born in Jerome, but had lived most of his life in Delaware.
Wells was employed for 29 years at the Sunray Stove Co. and 20 years at
Delo Screw Products Co.,
He was the oldest living past master of the Hiram Masonic Lodge. He
was also a member of the Sidney Moore Council, Ancient and Accepted Scottish
Rite, Columbus and the Ohio Persian Society.
Surviving are his wife, Laura, and a daughter, Miss Pearle Wells, at
home and a niece.
Friends may call at the Bennett-Brown Funeral home after 3 p.m. Monday.
Officers and members of Hiram Masonic Lodge will hold services at the
funeral home at 7:30 p.m. Monday.
Funeral services will be held at 1 p.m. Tuesday with the Rev. Thomas
Taylor, Asbury United Methodist Church officiating.
Burial will be in Oak Grove Cemetery.
[Source: Delaware Gazette, Delaware, Ohio, Saturday, April 5, 1969, p. 3]

Clare S. Wells
Funeral services for Clare S. Wells, of 161 N. Union St., who died
Friday, were held Tuesday afternoon from the Bennett-Brown Funeral home by
the Rev. Thomas Taylor of Asbury United Methodist Church.
Pallbearers were Sherman Moist, Carl Reynolds, Richard Snouffer, John
Evans, Harold and Ralph Gooding. Burial was in Oak Grove Cemetery.

SUMMERFIELD -- Mrs. Eugenia M. Campbell, 87, of Lewisville Route 1 in the Burkhart community, died at 6 a.m. Tuesday (April 8) at her home following a short illness. DEATH

Chester E. Paulus

Source: Beacon

 

Chester R. Paulus was born November 1, 1902 at Woodsfield, the son of J. A. and Catherine Latta Paulus. He departed this life April 14, 1969, at his home on Woodsfield Route 3. He was 66 years, five months and thirteen days old at the time of his death.

Mr. Paulus was a farmer and oil field worker. He was a member of St. Paul's United Church of Christ.

Surviving are his wife, Geneva Polen Paulus; three sons, David Paulus of the home; William Paulus, of Miltonsburg and Elwood Paulus of Lewisville; two sisters, Mrs. Clarence (Edna) Neisz of Woodsfield and Mrs. Ethel Christman of Woodsfield; three brothers, Sam Paulus of Route 3, Woodsfield; Herbert Paulus, of Redlands, California and John Paulus of Massillon; five grandchildren and several nieces and nephews, also a lot of friends and neighbors.

One brother and one sister preceded him in death.

Funeral services were held Wednesday afternoon, April 16th at two o'clock, in the Bauer and Turner Funeral Chapel, with Rev., George Corbitt officiating. Burial was in Oaklawn Cemetery.

DEATH
Name: Rev. Edward W. Brueseke, D. D.
Source: South Bend Tribune, Indiana
Issue: September 22, 1969
Collection of Beryl Christman Claus
Reverend Edward W. Brueseke, D. D.,64, of 235 South St. Peter St, pastor of Zion United Church of Christ and a leader in community and ecumenical affairs, died at 1:15 a.m. today in St. Josephs Hospital, where he was admitted Saturday night.
He came to South Bend March 1, 1948, from Sandusky, Ohio, where he had served as pastor of Emmanuel Church. Prior to that he had been pastor of St. Peters Church, Lewisville, Ohio from 1928 to 1932.
He was born on April 1, 1905 in St. Louis, Missouri, and was graduated from Elmhurst College, Elmhurst, Illinois, and Eden Theological Seminary, Webster Groves, Missouri. In 1953, Elmhurst awarded him an honorary doctorate.
He married Jolanda Sommer on August 2, 1928, in St. Louis. She survives along with two sons, Reverend Richard S. of St. Louis and Harold E. of South Bend; three grandchildren and two sisters, Mrs. Louis Hecht and Mrs. Almar Oakleye both of St. Louis.
Friends may call from 2 to 4 and 7 to 9 p.m. Tuesday and 9 a.m. until noon Wednesday in the funeral home. Interment will be in St. Joseph Valley Memorial Park.
Memorial services will be conducted at 2 p.m. Thursday in Zion united Church of Christ, Dr. Harry Bredeweg, minister of the Indiana-Kentucky Conference of the United Church , officiating.

Bucyrus-Chester Samuel Schwartz, 76, of Bucyrus died at 1 a.m. Sunday
in Bucyrus Community Hospital following a six-week illness.
He was born April 8, 1893, in Hannibal, son of Samuel and Matilda
Seebright Schwartz. His wife, the former Rose Ackerman, survives. The
couple celebrated their golden wedding anniversary in 1966.
A member of the Epworth United Methodist Church and the King's Workers
Class, he had been a farmer since 1916.
Mr. Schwartz leaves five children, Mrs. Robert Kibler, Mrs. Paul
Wagner, Mrs. Robert Weidemaier, Leslie and Esther all of Bucyrus. There are
15 grandchildren and four great-grandchildren.
He also is survived by a brother, Charles Schulze of Bucyrus. A
brother and two sisters preceded him in death.
Services will be Wednesday at 1:30 p.m. at the Wise Funeral Home with
Rev. Donald Taylor officiating. Burial will be in Oakwood Cemetery.
Friends may call at the funeral home Tuesday night. The family's
favorite benevolence is the church.
[Source: The Marion Star, Marion, Ohio, Monday, January 26, 1970, p. 7]

James Brownfield
Funeral services were held at 2 p. m. Monday at the Seneca Valley Church of Christ (Calais) for James Brownfield, 83, Calais, who died Friday evening, Feb. 27, [1970] at the home of a daughter, Mrs. Edward (Georgianna) Starr, of Barnesville, where he had been making his home for the past several months.  A retired farmer, he was born Jan. 21, 1887, in Monroe County near Calais, a son of Stephen and Lena Wells Brownfield.  Mr. Brownfield was a member of the Seneca Valley Church of Christ.
His wife, Blanche G. Brownfield, died Aug. 7, 1969.  In addition to the daughter at whose home he died, Mr. Brownfield is survived by five other daughters, Mrs. Henry (Mabel) Starr of Quaker City, Mrs. Kenneth (Stella) Mitchell of Bellaire, Mrs. Hobart (Bessie) Bunting and Mrs. Donald (Mary Lou) Broomhall, both of Barnesville, Mrs. Leroy (June) Hanson of Lewisville; three sons, Woodrow Brownfield of Bethesda, Oscar Brownfield of Woodsfield R. D. and Herbert Brownfield of Alliance; 30 grandchildren and 38 great-grandchildren, a total of 77 descendants.  Also surviving are a sister, Mrs. Elizabeth Miracle of Zanesville; two brothers, Fred Brownfield of Thornville and Keyser Brownfield of Newark.
Evangelist James Gallagher officiated at the funeral and burial followed in Calais Cemetery.

1970
(Clement Gregory Zwick was born on 07 Feb 1894 in Franklin, Monroe Co., OH.. He died on 08 Apr 1970 in Louisville, Stark Co., OH.)
Clement G. Zwick, age 76, of 525 Edwards st, Louisville, died Wednesday, April 8 [1970], in his home. He had been a resident of Louisville for 47 years. He was a retired employee of the United Engineering & Foundry Co. of Canton, where he had worked as a foreman until his retirement in 1959. After his retirement he worked at the First Federal Savings & Loan Co., Louisville branch. He was a member of St. Louis Catholic Church and an honorary life member of the Louisville Knights of Columbus Council 2530.
He is survived by his wife, Josephine of the home; two daughters, Mrs. Ray (Ann) Wilour of Miami, Fla, and Mrs. Bruce (Carolyn) Kittinger of Louisville; one son, Robert Zwick of Belton, South Carolina; one sister, Mrs. Martha Reichman of Miltonsburg, O.; and six grandchildren.
A Mass of Resurrection was sung in St. Louis Church on Saturday with burial in the church cemetery. Paquelet Funeral Home was in charge of the arrangements.
 

April 1970

Marriage

Christman-Stoehr

Source:

 

Miss Connie Stoehr, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Stoehr, of Woodsfield, Route one, became the bride of Mr. Harry Christman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Gilbert Christman, of Sardis Route one, were married on Saturday, April eighteenth at three o'clock in the afternoon in a double ring ceremony at the United Baptist Church. Reverend Earnest Hulsey officiated at the vows, and Miss Esther Brown presented the organ music.

Given in marriage by her father, the bride wore a floor length gown of satin with pressed lilies of the valley. The sleeves were of silk organza with embroidered lilies of the valley. The short veil was held in place by a bow of silk organza. The colonial bouquet was of red roses and lilies of the valley.

Miss Delores Stoehr, sister of the bride was maid of honor, and Miss Kathy Christman, sister of the bridegroom, was bridesmaid. They wore identical dresses of copen blue taffeta, with a bow at the waist. They carried colonial bouquets of white carnations with a tint of blue.

The mother of the bride chose a cocoa suit with white accessories, and the mother of the bridegroom wore a mint green dress with white accessories. Their corsages were of white carnations.

Lester Christman served his brother as best man. Fred Stoehr, brother of the bride, was usher.

A small reception followed at the home of the bride. Decorations for the reception were furnished my Martha Covert.

After a wedding trip to Lexington, Kentucky, the couple is residing in Antioch.

Source: The Spirit of Democracy

 

Marion F. Stephen, 74, Woodsfield Route 3, died Thursday, June 4, at Barnesville Hospital. He was born in Senaca Township November 19, 1895, a son of Randolph and Nancy Lucas Stephen.

He was a member of St. John's Catholic Church of Miltonsburg.

Surviving are his widow, Gertrude E. Miller Stephen; five daughters, Mrs. James R. (Mildred) Winland, Mrs. Sylvan (Mary) Carpenter, and Mrs. Dale (Emma) Carpenter, all of Barnesville, Mrs. Walter (Alberta) Ackerman, Lewisville, and Mrs. William (Dorothy) Dudley, Columbus; two sons, Francis of Lewisville and James of the home; nine grandchildren and two great-grandchildren; one sister, Mrs. Clem (Rebecca) Burkhart, Miltonsburg. One brother and two sisters and a grandson preceded him in death.

1970
Wesley W. Schaub
Wesley W. Schaub, 73, of 2804 12th St. SW, died this morning in Aultman Hospital after a brief illness. He was president of Schaub Electrical Contractors and had been in the electrical business for 55 years.  A native of Monroe County, he had lived in Canton for 60 years and was an Army veteran of World War I.
        He was a member of the board of electrical examiners for the City of Canton and a member of Local 540, International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, of which he was a member.  Mr. Schaub was also a member of National Electrical Contractors Association, Canton Lodge, Loyal Order of Moose, and North Canton Aerie, Fraternal Order of Eagles.
        He is survived by a son, Wesley W. Schaub Jr., and a daughter, Mrs. Sylvester (Stella) Paulus, both of Canton; a brother, Homer Schaub of East Sparta, and a sister, Mrs. Effie Jane Latta of Canton.
        Rev. Harold Henniger will conduct services Friday at 1 p.m. in Welch funeral home. Burial will be in Sunset Hills Burial Park.  Friends may call Thursday 2 to 4 and 7 to 9 p.m.
 
Note:  Although he was always referred to as Wes, his school listings and otherdocuments refer to him as Weber Wesley. The old Bible lists it asWeber Wesley Schaub. Junior (his son) says his father always signed his name as Wesley W. Schaub. "Back those days when Uncle Wes was young no one legally changed their name." --Aunt Jan
 
1970
Ben F. Dixon
SOURCE:  The National Genealogical Society Quarterly, Volumes 1-85, 1600's-1900's. Page 57-58
Old-time members of the National Genealogical Society will remember a tall, bald man in a Navy officer's uniform, whose smile and hearty handshake exuded warmth and cordiality, and whose booming voice infected his hearers with the same enthusiasm for genealogical research and for extending the spheres of the influence of the society.
This was Ben F. Dixon, a native of Kahoka, Missouri, and a long time resident of San Diego, California.  It is with deep regret that we received word of his death at his home, 6008 Arosa Street, San Diego, on Saturday, 27 June 1970, at the age of 78.
In his adopted city he was Curator of the Junipero Serra Museum in Presido Park, 1949-1955, and for 11 years taught history at Adult Evening School.  He started the Walking Tours of the Old Town.  He was a member of the Squibob Chapter of E Clampas Vitus, an organization founded in the Gold Rush Days by men who like to mix history and fun.  In 1968 on a visit to Washington (D C), he addressed the Society on the historical and genealogical work being accomplished in San Diego.
His publications included "Contributions of Haiti to the Independence of the United States, 1776-1826" (1950), which won an award from the Haitian Government; "Diario, The Journal of Padre Serra " (editor; 2nd edition, 1967), and with Mrs Dixon, "Five Generations of American Dwelles" (1960).
The Society extends its deepest sympathy to his widow, the former Alice L. Dwelle; his sons Dale and John and his daughter Mary Alice   Six grand children also survive.  Burial was in Greenwood Mausoleum.                   Milton Rubincam.

1970
Blanche A. Foster nee Herlan
TIMES RECORDER, ZANESVILLE, OHIO, 8 Aug 1970
Mrs. Blanche A. Foster [aka, Alma B. "Blanche" (Herlan) Foster], 84, of Drake Nursing Home on Findley avenue, retired housemother of the old Bethesda School of Nursing, died at 5:05 p.m. Friday (Aug. 7) at the nursing home where she had been a patient several years.  She was born June 1, 1886, in Summerfield, a daughter of John W. and Sarah Kent Herlan. She spent most of her life in the Zanesville area. Her husband, Delbert G. Foster, died in 1942.  Mrs. Foster was Bethesda housemother 17 years before retiring in 1964. She was a member of Grace United Methodist Church.
She leaves a daughter, Mrs. Donald (Fern) Lane of West Pike; a son, John Foster of Jackson; a brother, Elbert Herlan of Parma; seven grandchildren; and six great-grandchildren; and a number of nieces and nephews. A daughter, three brothers and four sisters are deceased.  Friends may call at Blue Avenue Chapel of Bolin Funeral Home 2 to 4 and 7 to 9 p.m. Sunday.
 

Aug 1970

MARRIAGE

Everly-Christman

Source:

Lena Christman and Sgt. David Everly were united in a Turkish civil ceremony August 13 at Karamursel, Turkey. . On August 16, at 6:00 p.m. Chaplain John Stuller officiated at the nuptial wedding at the base chapel.

The bride is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Christman and granddaughter of Mrs. Nora Stephen, all of Summerfield.

Sgt. Everly is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Everly of Caldwell Route. His grandparents are Mr. and Mrs. Harden Everly of Sarahsville and Mrs. Nellie Johnson of Akron.

The bride's street length gown was fashioned of lace and silk organza with underlying white crepe. A band of satin ribbon adorned the empire waist above a flowing full skirt. The shoulder length veil was also of lace. The dress was made by Mrs. Joseph Burbacher of Summerfield.

Mr. and Mrs. Paul Przymus, friends of the bride and groom form Minnesota, attended the couple.

Mrs. Everly graduated from Shenandoah High School with class of 1967 and attended Ohio University. This past year she was employed as a teacher at Batesville Elementary and is presently enrolled at the University of Maryland, European Division.

The bridegroom is a 1966 graduate of Shenandoah High School and entered the U. S. Air Force in August 1967.

Until completion of his tour they will reside at 29 Yeni CamiSokak, Yalava, Turkey.

Their complete address is: Sgt. and Mrs. David Everly, Box 774 Det. 94, A. P. O. N.Y. 09324

September 2, 1970

WEDDING

Wade-Morris

Source: Monroe County Beacon

Wedding vows were exchanged by Miss Linda Lou Wade, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Wade of Barnesville, and Mr. Rodney Dale Morris, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ermie Morris of Woodsfield Route three, on Saturday afternoon, June twentieth. The double ring ceremony was performed by Minister J.V.A. Traylor at his home at five o'clock with members of the immediate families present.

The bride wore a street length gown of silk organza over taffeta with an empire waistline and long sleeves. Her shoulder length veil was held by a floral band. She carried a bouquet of white carnations on a white Bible, a gift of the bridegroom.

Miss Almeta Hayes, friend of the bride, was maid of honor. She wore a turquoise gown identical to the bride's. Her bouquet was of blue tinted carnations.

Mr. Kenneth Morris, brother of the bridegroom, served as best man.

The reception was held at St. John's Parish Hall, Miltonsburg, immediately after the ceremony.

Reception hostesses were Mrs. LaVern Christman, Mrs. Danny Watson, Mrs. Lela Christman and Mrs. Ed Gillespie. Miss Sharon Strous was in charge of the guest book and Mrs. David Lallathin registered the gifts.

A dance followed the reception with music by the County Serenaders.

Mrs. Morris is a graduate of Barnesville High School. Mr. Morris is a graduate of Skyvue High School and is employed by Landmark in Bethesda.

The couple is residing at 210 South Broadway, Barnesville.

Out of town guests were from Mansfield, Cadiz, Akron, Massillon, Bethesda, Flushing, Columbus, North Lawrence, Port Washington, Ashland, Quaker City, Shelby, Lewisville and Westerville.

Obituary of Vernon W. Haren,
(born 1900 in Miltonsburg, Ohio; died in Louisville, Stark Co, Ohio, 1970)
Vernon (Vern) W. Haren, 79, of 210 East Gorgas st, Louisville, died suddenly Tuesday evening, Sept. 8 [1970]. He had lived in the Louisville area for 58 years and worked in research at H-P Products Co. of Louisville for ten years, retiring in 1960. He then drove a school bus for the Louisville School System for 5 years.
He was a member of St. Louis Catholic Church and of Louisville Knights of Columbus Council 2530. His wife, Lillian Bishop Haren, had preceded him in death in 1964.
Survived by many nieces and nephews, the Mass of the Resurrection was held Friday morning at the church and K of C services held in Paquelet Funeral Home Thursday evening. Burial was made in St. Louis Church cemetery.

Esta Marie Burkhart

Source:

Esta Marie Burkhart, daughter of John W. and Clara Ackerman Christman was born near Calais, Ohio June 18, 1908 and departed this life March 1, 1971 in Cambridge hospital following a long illness. She was 62 years, eight months and thirteen days of age.

She was united in marriage with William Burkhart, of Sycamore Valley, Ohio in 1937 and to this union five children were born. A daughter, Carolyn Marie, preceded her in death in 1944 in early infancy. Her husband, William, passed away February 19, 1968.

Surviving are four sons, John Burkhart of Cleveland, Ohio; Robert, Larry and Donald Burkhart, all of Sycamore Valley; eight grandchildren; three sisters, Mrs. Helen Starr of Summerfield Route 2; Mrs. Mary Hayes, of Quaker City Route 4; and Mrs. Cleo Carpenter, of Kent; four brothers, Gilbert Christman, of Fly; Howard Christman, of Lewisville Rt; Herbert Christman, of Summerfield Route 2, and Lee Christman, of Quaker City Route 4 and several nieces and nephew.

She was also preceded in death by her father in February 1959; her mother in January 1966, and a brother, Lester, in June 1918.

Esta was in all sincerity a mother at heart. Although in poor health, and as she bore her burden of affliction her ardent interest in her loved ones never ceased.

As the years slip away, memory reverts to the days when skies were blue and days were long and pleasant dreams were endless; when mother was near to smile, lend a guiding hand and to understand and care.

She has gone to her home eternal to begin earth's finished work, and she now finds the peace which was impossible for human hands to give.

Let me go, my soul is weary

Of the chain which binds me here;

Let my spirit bend its pinion

To a brighter, holier sphere.

And the hope that gives us courage

Is that, sometime we shall meet you

When we end this earthly strife.

 

Funeral services were held in the Creighton Ridge Church of Christ on Thursday afternoon, March 4, with Minister J. V. A. Traylor officiating. Interment was in the church cemetery with the Mallett Funeral home of Stafford in charge.

1971
Mrs. Barbara Johnson Lumbatis
Mrs. Barbara Johnson Lumbatis, 25, of Woodsfield, route 4, died Monday night (March 15, 1971) at the Barnesville Hospital.
She was born July 30, 1945, at West Frankfort, Ill, the daughter of Murile Johnson of Mt. Vernon, ILL., and Mrs. Lorraine Lewis of Evansville, Ind. She was a member of the Woodsfield Methodist Church and Rebecca Lodge.
Surviving in addition to her parents are her husband, Richard; one daughter, Kesha and one son, Kyle, both at home; three sisters, Mrs. Robert Johnson, Carla Lewis, and Francis Lewis, all of Evansville.
Friends received at the Bauer and Turner Funeral Home, Woodsfield, whre services will be held Thursday at 2 p.m. with Rev. George Bender officiating.
Interment in Friendship cemetery, Lewisville. Rebecca Lodge of Lewisville will conduct services at the funeral home Wednesday at 7:30 p.m.

Douglas Gene Betts, son of Lloyd Betts
Douglas Betts
Shelby - Douglas Gene Betts, 11 - year - old son of Mr. and Mrs. Lloyd
Betts of Tiro, RD 1, died Tuesday night at his home following an extended
illness.
Born in Galion, his entire life was spent in the Trio area. He
attended Buckeye East Elementary School and was a Cub Scout in Tiro Den 2,
Pack 105.
Survivors beside his parents include a brother, Daniel and sister,
Jeanise, both at home; his paternal grandparents, Mr. and Mrs. Theodore
Betts of Tiro, RD 1; his maternal grandparents, Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Artz of
Trio, RD 1 and his maternal great grandmother, Mrs. Grace Artz, Tiro RD 1.
[Source: News Journal, Mansfield, Ohio, Wednesday, April 21, 1971 p. 5]

Homer R. Rich
Jeffersonian Sat 28 Aug 1971
Eberle Funeral Home here has charge of arrangements for Homer R Rich, 96 Quaker City, R.D. 1.  Mr Rich died Saturday morning August 28, 1971 in Guernsey Memorial Hospital, Cambridge.  He was born May 11, 1875 in Noble County, a son of the late William and Margaret Miley Rich.  His wife, Alice Rich died July 22, 1954.
Mr Rich leaves one daughter, Mrs Ellis (Audry) Long, Quaker City, R.D. 1,; one son William Rich, Senecaville R.D. 1, and 10 grandchildren.

Ella.E. Jones, nee Hossman
February 26, 1972
Jones, Mrs. Ella E. Hossman, 80, of 5 twenty-third St., McMechen, died at 6 a.m. Saturday at home. Born in Sardis, Oct.23,1891, she was a daughter of the late Godfrey and Lena Rufener Hossman. A member of The Church of Christ, McMechen, she is survived by her husband, Everett Jones; two brothers, Ernest Hossman,Glen Dale; and George Hossman, St. Clairsville; a sister, Mrs. Elinor Long, Cobb Island,Md.; and several nieces and nephews.
Friends recieved at Altmeyer Funeral Home, 214 Marshall St. McMechen, Sunday from 2 to 4 and 7 to 9 p.m. Services in the chapel at 1 p.m. Tuesday with Mr. Thomas Harland Gatten officiating. Interment in Halcyon Hills Memorial Gardens.
